title: About
text:
Dr. Cat Fong



Research & perspective
I am a systems ecologist focused on resilience and sustainability across ecological and social systems. I work across marine and terrestrial systems—from coral reefs and aquaculture to wildfire and food production—to understand how systems respond to stress and how we can support outcomes that are both ecologically and socially durable.
My approach is integrative: I combine trait-based ecology, data synthesis, and collaboration with practitioners and communities to ask questions that matter for policy and management. I’m especially interested in how we can design research and partnerships that build resilience at multiple scales.



Research interests

Systems ecology — understanding feedbacks and linkages across ecosystems and human systems

Resilience — what makes systems persist, adapt, or transform under change

Sustainability — ecological and social dimensions of resource use and conservation

Cross-system research — marine and terrestrial; ecology, data science, and practice




Position
Assistant Research Scientist, National Center for Ecological Analysis and Synthesis (NCEAS)

title: Images and assets for your site
text:
This file is a short guide so you can add or swap images without touching code.



Put image files (e.g. face.jpg, forest.jpg, hero.jpg) in the same folder as your .qmd files (the root of catfong.github.io/).
The site already uses:

face.jpg — About page and Projects (trait-based seaweed section)
forest.jpg — Projects (Wildfire in the West)





To use a full-width hero image on the homepage instead of the gradient:

Add a file, e.g. hero.jpg, to the project root.
In index.qmd, change the hero block to use it. Replace the opening of the hero div with a version that sets a background image, e.g. in styles.scss add:
.hero-wrap.with-image {
  background-image: linear-gradient(var(--hero-overlay), var(--hero-overlay)), url('hero.jpg');
}
Then add the class with-image to the hero div in index.qmd.

Or keep the current gradient—it works with no image and stays bold and professional.




Unsplash (unsplash.com) — Search: “ecology”, “coral reef”, “forest resilience”, “sustainability”, “field research”, “woman scientist”.
Pexels (pexels.com) — Same kinds of terms; good for nature and people.
Your own — Field work, lab, or a clear headshot for face.jpg are strongest for a “fund her” vibe.




To embed a short video (e.g. 30–60 seconds about your work or a project):

Host it on YouTube or Vimeo (unlisted is fine).
In any .qmd file, add:
::: {.ratio .ratio-16x9}
<iframe src="YOUR_VIDEO_EMBED_URL" allowfullscreen></iframe>
:::

A single, high-impact hero image or one short video on the homepage can make the site feel even more engaging.

title: Projects
text:
I lead and contribute to projects that sit at the intersection of ecology, resilience, and sustainability—spanning wildfire, marine systems, and food production. Collaboration is central to how I work.



Building understanding and tools for wildfire resilience in western landscapes—working with partners to link ecology, risk, and community needs. This work connects systems thinking on the ground with data and decision support (e.g. Wildfire Risk Reduction Index).
Collaborators: Joe, Mona, Carlo, Erika — a tight team bringing field experience, modeling, and regional expertise together.



Wildfire and forest resilience






Advancing a trait-based framework for marine macroalgae to better understand ecology, resilience, and sustainable use. I’m developing this line of work with collaborators and am keen to expand partnerships—especially where traits meet aquaculture, restoration, or climate adaptation.



Trait-based seaweed ecology






Exploring how sustainability in food production can be understood and supported across systems—from aquaculture to terrestrial agriculture. Food systems are a critical nexus for resilience, equity, and ecology; I’m interested in research that connects these dimensions.

For publications, see Publications. To collaborate or discuss ideas, reach out via the links on About.
